abstract.text: Learn how we‚Äôve optimized the Swift and Objective-C runtimes to help you make your app smaller, quicker, and launch faster. Discover how you can get access to efficient protocol checks, smaller message send calls, and optimized ARC simply when you build your app with Xcode 14 and update your deployment target.

inlineContent.text: Example:

code: if let value = value as? CustomLoggable { // üëàüèª protocol check

inlineContent.text: Whenever possible, this check is optimized away at build time, in the compiler
However, we don‚Äôt always have enough information yet, so this check often needs to happen in the runtime, with the help of protocol check metadata
With this metadata, the runtime knows whether this particular object really does conform to the protocol
Part of the metadata is built at compile time, but a lot can only be built at launch time, particularly when using Swift generics
on apps that rely heavily in Swift, this could add up to half the launch time
New this year:
protocol checks are pre-computed as part of the dyld closure for the app executable and any dylib it uses at launch (a.k.a. this is done at app installation time)
enabled even for existing apps when running on iOS 16, tvOS 16, or watchOS 9.
with new compilers and linker in Xcode 14,message send calls are up to
8 bytes
smaller, down from
12 bytes
, on ARM64
binaries up to 2% smaller overall
enabled by Xcode 14, even when targeting an older OS release as deployment target
Defaults to balanced performance and size optimization
Opt into optimizing for size only using
linker flag
Prior:
whenever we interact with objc models, we almost always end up needing an instruction to call
, even when doing property accesses
this is because at compile time, we don‚Äôt know which method to call, therefore we ask objc runtime using
to find the right method

code: NSDateComponents* dateComponents = [[NSDateComponents alloc] init]; // 2x üëàüèª compiler emits bl _objc_msgSend

inlineContent.text: to tell the runtime which method to call, we have to pass a selector to these
calls. This needs two more instructions to prepare the selector, each of these instructions takes 4 bytes on ARM64.
Example:

code: ldr  x1 [x1, selector "dateFromComponents"] // üëàüèª 4 bytes on ARM 64

inlineContent.text: in conclusion, for each
call, we‚Äôre using 12 bytes (4B for
, 8B for the selector)
What‚Äôs new:
for any given selector, it‚Äôs always the same code, example from above:

code: adrp x1 [selector "dateFromComponents"]     // üëàüèª always the same instruction for dateFromComponents
ldr  x1 [x1, selector "dateFromComponents"] // üëàüèª always the same instruction for dateFromComponents

inlineContent.text: we can share this same code and only emit it once
per selector
instead of at every message send
we do this via a helper function, and call that function instead
this function is called Selector Stub
Therefore we go from this:
to this:

code: // Where the _objc_msgSend$dateFromComponents Selector stub is defined ONCE per program

inlineContent.text: However
still needs to jump to the actual message send code (the Call stub), therefore we‚Äôre doing two jumps in our machine code (one to go to the Selector stub, one to the Call stub)

Based on the optimization that we would like, we can merge the Selector and Call stub (making only one jump), or we can keep them separate. This is the difference between the default behavior (balanced performance and size optimization) and the optimized for size one (
linker flag):
vs.

code: // Where the _objc_msgSend$dateFromComponents Selector stub is defined ONCE per program

inlineContent.text: retain/release calls are now up to 4 bytes smaller, down from 8 on ARM64
binaries up to 2% smaller overall
enabled by new compilers in Xcode 14
requires new runtime support, hence your deployment target must be iOS 16, tvOS 16, or watchOS 9
thanks to ARC (automatic reference counting), our code compiles into a lot of retain/release calls
whenever we make a copy of a pointer to an object, we need to increment its retain count to keep it live
we do that by calling into the runtime, using
when our variables go out of scope, we then need to decrement the retain count using
in actuality, the compiler will do some optimizations that will avoid some of these calls
functions are just plain C functions
they take a single argument, the object to be released
with ARC, the compiler inserts calls to these C functions, passing the appropriate object pointers
Because of that, these calls have to respect the C calling convention, defined by our platform ABI (Application Binary Interface)
this results in extra
instructions just for passing the pointer in the right register
Optimization:

By specializing retain/release with a custom calling convention, the system can opportunistically use the right variant depending on where the object pointer already is, meaning we don‚Äôt need the extra
instructions
skipping these
instructions saves the 4 bytes
enabled by ObjC runtime changes (automatically happens when running iOS 16, tvOS 16, watchOS 9, or macOS 13)
with additional compiler changes, the app binary is also smaller (requires deployment target must be iOS 16, tvOS 16)
What is Autorelease elision?
When we call a method that returns a value, we call
on the returned object
on the method‚Äôs body, we don‚Äôt call
on the returned object, as that would release the object from memory
instead we call
, so the method caller can retain it

code: return [newValue autorelease]; // üëàüèª we don't release, we autorelease, so the caller (above)
//    can retain it before the instance gets released.

inlineContent.text: tells the runtime that we‚Äôre returning an object that will immediately be retained
thanks to some improvements in both compiler and Objc runtime,
overhead is now cheaper, and with clever use of pointers is faster as well
Missing anything? Corrections?

metadata.title: Improve app size and runtime performance

abstract.text: Session notes shared by the community for the community.
Xcode 14, Swift 5.7, iOS 16, macOS 13 (Ventura), tvOS 16, watchOS 9.

doc://WWDCNotes/documentation/WWDCNotes/.title: Link fast: Improve build and launch times

abstract.text: Discover how to improve your app‚Äôs build and runtime linking performance. We‚Äôll take you behind the scenes to learn more about linking, your options, and the latest updates that improve the link performance of your app.
Software engineer with a strong passion for well-written code, thought-out composable architectures, automation, tests, and more.

Join us for an update on Swift. We‚Äôll take you through performance improvements, explore more secure and extensible Swift packages, and share advancements in Swift concurrency. We‚Äôll also introduce you to Swift Regex, better generics, and other tools built into the language to help you write more flexible & expressive code.
